journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Tuning of a new class of robust fractional-order proportional–integral–derivative controllers

author-notes.corresp: *University of Poitiers, LAII-ENSIP, 2 rue Pierre Brousse, B.P. 633, 86022 Poitiers, France. email: mammar.tenoutit@univ-poitiers.fr

abstract.p: A new class of fractional proportional–integral (PI) and PI–derivative (PID) controllers is defined, based on a closed-loop reference model expressing the dynamical and robust performances. Moreover, the filtering of the derivative action is explicitly formulated using a generalized second-order reference model. Numerical simulations with simple systems illustrate some general principles that can be used as guidelines for the tuning of fractional PID controllers. For more complex or delayed systems, a tuning method based on the time moments approach is also proposed. Numerical examples illustrate the capabilities of this tuning technique.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Fractional control is a prosperous research domain among the applications of fractional differentiation [1]. The interest for this type of control has its origins in the seminal works of Bode [2] in the 1940s, followed by those of Manabe [3] in the 1960s. Quantitative feedback theory [4] can be interpreted as fractional control, though its formulation does not refer explicitly to fractional derivation. However, the works of Oustaloup have really popularized fractional control, known as CRONE control (Commande Robuste d’Ordre Non Entier, meaning non integer order robust control) [5–7]. Oustaloup’s approach relies explicitly on fractional differentiation and exhibits clearly its robust performances, from CRONE 1 to CRONE 3.

CRONE controllers are renowned for their robust performances but they require some know-how for their implementation. Many researchers have investigated simpler fractional controllers, in standard structure as proportional–integral–derivative (PID), while preserving some robust performances, but not challenging CRONE controllers. Thus, they have defined the fractional PID as a generalization of the classical PID, with the structure
P
I
α
D
β
, where the fractional orders
α
and
β
are supplementary tuning possibilities used to improve the performances of the PID controller [8]. Since the first works of Podlubny [9], a great number of publications have been proposed, mainly focused on techniques to tune the five parameters of this new controller (see for example references [1] and [9] to [16] and the references therein). Though in their comparative results the different authors insist on the interest of the fractional orders
α
and
β
, they do not present simple and general principles giving guidelines for the choice of these orders in order to satisfy conventional control design objectives, particularly robustness objectives.

So this paper is intended to propose some general principles dealing with fractional PI and PID controllers, in order to justify their new fractional structure and to propose some elementary design techniques satisfying robustness objectives. The main characteristic of the approach is the importance given to a closed-loop reference model, including robustness and dynamical performances.

The proposed design technique provides an exact solution for fractional PI and PID controller parameters applied to first- and second-order systems. For more complex systems, this technique would provide higher-order controllers. Users prefer to use a standard structure, like PI or PID. Thus, because there is no longer an exact solution to impose exactly the closed-loop dynamics, it is necessary to calculate an approximate one. So, an alternative tuning method is proposed based on the time moments approach.

The method of moments has already been used successfully for the design of PID controllers [17, 18]. This technique is based on the approximation of a reference model by the closed loop of the control system, using the equality of the first time moments. Here, this technique is used for the design of the fractional PID controller. Because a major problem is noise sensitivity of the closed loop (or equivalently impulses in the control input), it is necessary to pay particular attention to the open-loop reference model derived from the CRONE template, in order to reduce significantly the peak value of the control input, while preserving robustness to system static gain variations. The present authors also propose a method to take into account a time delay of the system by including it in the open-loop reference model.

In section 2, some definitions related to fractional integration and differentiation are recalled. A new class of robust fractional PI and PID controllers is introduced in section 3. In section 4, in order to generalize the application of these fractional controllers to more complex systems, a tuning technique based on the method of moments is proposed. Numerical examples are proposed in sections 3 and 4 to illustrate the capabilities of these new fractional PID controllers.

sec.title: 2.1 Fractional integration
sec.p:
Fractional integration is defined by the Riemann–Liouville integral [19–21]. The
n
th-order integral (
n
real positive) of the function
f ( t )
is defined by the relation

I

( f ( t ) )
is the convolution of the function
f ( t )
with the impulse response
of the fractional integration operator whose Laplace transform is

The fractional-order integrator is infinite-dimensional; practically, it has to be approximated by a finite-dimension integer-order system. It has been demonstrated using a frequency approach [20, 22] that a fractional integrator can be approximated by an integer modal model [23]
with
see reference [23] for practical implementation.

sec.p:

sec.title: 3 A New Class of Fractional PI and PID Controllers

sec.title: 3.2 Reference model of the closed loop
sec.p: Proposed by Bode [2], Bode’s ideal transfer function ensures a constant phase margin around a frequency of interest and therefore a constant overshoot of the time responses to the open-loop gain variations. So it is interesting to take this ideal function as a reference model to achieve robust performance. This ideal transfer function was also defined by Oustaloup [5] as an ideal template for the second-generation CRONE controller (CRONE 2), that is
in order to get rid of static gain variations. An ideal closed loop refers to this CRONE template

It is well known that

is the peak value for the PI controller: its mastery is important because it can saturate the control input and also it reflects noise sensitivity of the closed loop. It is easy to demonstrate [25] that

So, one of the interests of the fractional reference model is to reduce noise sensitivity of the closed loop.

sec.title: 3.5.3 Example 3: filtered fractional PID controller
sec.p:
In order to decrease the peak values of
u ( t )

n = 0 . 4

u ( 0 ) = 11 . 8

m = 0 . 37
,

0

G = 1
). In this situation, there is no robustness, as displayed in Fig. 6. It can be concluded that a realistic fractional PID controller is able to achieve better robustness performances than a classical PID controller.

sec.title: 3.5.4 Conclusions
sec.p:
The
( PI
)
n
controller is adapted to first-order systems (it provides robust performances when static gain changes occur), while the
( PI
D
f
)
n
controller exhibits the same properties with second-order systems. The dynamical and robust performances of these two fractional controllers are directly connected to their respective closed-loop reference models (10) and (34). The fractional order
n
provides robust performances and produces a decrease of the peak value of the control input. Moreover, it is necessary to take into account explicitly the filtering of the derivative action during the tuning phase, with the help of an adapted reference model like (34). A compromise between robust performances and the filtering of the derivative action is necessary in order to get a realistic control input.

sec.title:
4 Time Moments Approach to The Design of
( PI
D
f
)

Controllers
4.1 Introduction
sec.p:
For a third-order system, the previous approach provides a fractional
( PI
D
f
D
f
2
)
n
controller ensuring equality of the closed-loop and of an appropriate fractional reference model. Nevertheless, one can consider that this controller structure is too complex and prefer to use a standard structure, like
PI
D
f
or
( PI
D
f
)
n
. Thus, because there is no longer an exact solution to impose exactly the closed-loop dynamics, it is necessary to calculate an approximate one.

Practically, the
( PI
D
f
)
n
controller parameters will be tuned in order to get a good approximation of the reference model dynamics, while preserving stability and robustness. It is for this reason that there exist a great number of methods for the tuning of PID controllers (and of course fractional
PIDs
). In order to illustrate this necessary approximation principle, a tuning method for
( PI
D
f
)
n
controllers using a time moments approach [18, 26] is proposed.

sec.title: 4.2.1 Definition of the time moments
sec.p:
The time moments
A
k
( h )
of an impulse response
h ( t )
are the coefficients of the Taylor series expansion of its Laplace transform
H ( s )

where

where
A
k
( h )
is the
k

h ( t )

sec.title: 4.2.2 Properties of time moments
sec.p: Let some properties of the first three time moments be recalled.

list-item.p:
The zeroth-order moment
A
0
, represents the impulse response area, it is also equal to the static gain of the transfer function.

The first-order moment
A
1
, represents mean time of the impulse response. For a first-order system,
A
1
= τ
A
0
, where
τ
represents the time constant of the system. More generally,
A
1
is used to characterize the time response of the considered system.

The second-order moment
A
2
, characterizes the dispersion of the impulse response around its mean time.

sec.title: 4.3 Time moments equivalence of two transfer functions
sec.p:
Consider two transfer functions
H
1
( s )
and
H
2
( s )

J + 1
first moments are equal [27]

Indeed, when
J → ∞
,
H
1
( s )
and
H
2
( s )
are strictly equal.

Practically, only
J + 1
moments are used to approximate the two impulse responses
h
1
( t )
and
h
2
( t )

The basic idea is that
h
1
( t ) →
h
2
( t )
when
J
is increased.

Rigorously, these tuning relations do not guarantee stability of the closed loop. Practically, an appropriate choice of the reference model
m
(i.e. overshoot) and
w
0
(i.e. time response) parameters permits to guarantee stability. For more complex systems, the combined use of time and frequency moments [28] makes it possible to guarantee stability while preserving dynamical performances (thanks to time moments). Another way to guarantee stability is to use output feedback with the Lyapunov technique, while expressing dynamical and robust performances of the reference model with time moments [29].

sec.title: 4.4.3 Controller design for time delay system
sec.p:
Time delay systems represent an important class of industrial systems, particularly in chemical engineering. For large values of the time delay
T
, it is necessary to use the Smith predictor (or the fractional Smith predictor). For small values of the time delay (when it corresponds to the modelling of high-order dynamics or identification uncertainty), a
( PI
D
f
)
n
controller remains a good solution.

( s )

n

n
and
T

n
in order to get the same overshoot as in the no-delay case.

A

sec.title: 5 Conclusion
sec.p:
Many researchers have shown interest in the tuning of
P
I
α
D
β
controllers generalizing the conventional PID, but generally without defining explicitly the desired performances, and moreover without filtering the derivative action. Using a fractional closed-loop reference model to express the desired dynamics and robust performances, a new class of fractional PI and PID controllers has been introduced, which are able to impose completely the dynamics of first- and second-order systems while ensuring robustness to static gain variations. In order to take into account the necessary filtering of the derivative action, a new generalized fractional second-order reference model has been defined, which makes it possible to reduce the peak value of the control input and noise sensitivity of the closed loop. The first objective of this paper has been to formulate some fundamental guidelines useful for the tuning of robust fractional PID controllers. The second objective has been to propose a tuning technique for
( PI
D
f
)
n
fractional controllers based on the method of moments. This technique allows a good specification of the closed-loop system dynamics (damping, time response) thanks to the time moments of the reference model. Robust and dynamical performances are specified by the fractional open-loop reference model where the fractional order makes it possible for robustness to gain variations of the system. Numerical examples have shown that this tuning technique is able to provide robust controllers while preserving noise sensitivity of the closed loop, by explicit filtering of the derivative action.
In future research works, it will be interesting to define and to analyse other closed-loop reference models, in order to investigate more sophisticated robust specifications.
